author: stickman07738
body:
I was in QCOM rode the telecom craze high from early 1998 - Mar 2000 - thought I was a genius (six figures and growing daily) - then end of Y2K in January (20% drop) rushed in purchased more as "*it was a bargain*", then March another 20% drop - BOOM - lost $300K in 4-6 weeks.

Luckily - I always funded my retirement fully first (401K, IRA,...) and had some blue-chips that survived.

Did I see it coming - F--K no; no one ever does. This is why I know TSLA will crash - I hear the same excuses - it is different this time (NOT). Best to take profits than trying to catch a falling knife.

Good luck in your investments.

author: diegobomber
body:
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2021-01-14/intel-is-the-last-chance-for-u-s-semi-leadership-harvard-s-shih-video

Intel right now just can't keep up on the PC front. It can't keep running hotter on the same process to try to match the performance from smaller processes working cohesively (AMD). And that's just for chips on x86, Apple now has brought ARM as a real alternative to that space as well. Intel doesn't even really tangibly exist on the mobile side or on tablets as it's Qualcomm and Apple running that show. They will need to make big changes going forward to gain market share back from foreign chip makers in these spaces.

author: ron_leflore
body:
This is my personal experience.

I'm somewhat of a value investor. I had a target price where I would sell my position back then. I wasn't invested in the highly speculative dotcom stuff, but many other companies got caught up in the bubble. I was primarily invested in Qualcomm.

I hit my target in the summer of 1999, but I didn't sell right away, things were increasing at an unreal rate. I remember one day QCOM went up by more than 100 points. I made more on QCOM that day than my annual salary. By the fall, I was looking at huge capital gains and I decided to just hold out until the new year to sell that way I could delay paying the capital gains tax by another year.

So, I sold out of my position the first week of January. I know people say the bubble popped in March, but I remember the decline starting in January. I've always thought it was because of people like me, trying to delay tax payments by a year.

author: Kierik
body:
I think we have to be realistic with this stock. If this hit $6 in its current state it would worth 828B or slightly less than half as much as Apple inc. They have 138B outstanding shares and a current market cap of $110M. They would have to get a historically enormous  judgement to justify a 10X increase. This will not hit $6 without reverse splits. 

IANAL but looking at past cases I think people are looking at billions when they should be looking at millions plus royalties. 

In 2019 Qualcomm sued apple for infringement and got a judgement of $31 million in damages on about 50-60 billion in revenue. Philip Morris's revenue in 2020 was somewhere in the range of 30B with only about 8B in net income.

author: stoney-the-tiger
body:
ISAs are more complicated than that.  Think of it like this, x86\_64 aka AMD64 is a complicated language with a deep, convoluted legacy like English.  ARM64 is a more simplified language with a more direct lineage but some creolization (Apple, Qualcomm, Samsung, Broadcom, MediaTek, etc...), like Spanish.  There is another ISA that is up and coming called RISC-V which is even more streamlined and efficient, like Esperanto.

In 10-20 years, the odds of all 3 of these being around is about the same as the odds of these spoken languages being around.  There is a possibility that ARM may overtake x86 and there is also a possibility that RISC V will overtake both of them.  

Intel's troubles are more with manufacturing than with CE design.  If they get back on track with manufacturing, they will be goose that lays golden eggs for years to come.

That is a HUGE "if" though.

author: WestmontOG07
body:
I've been doing it for about a year now. In FY 2020, I made approximately $34,591.71 BY day and week trading \*\*(Please keep in mind that the trades I made were with excess cash on the sidelines and my "core" portfolio, was never touched so that appreciated substantially, just as I am sure everyone else's "Long term hold portfolio also appreciated" from March thru year end 2020). My day trading thesis was that if I could make $300 a day, when the charts of a particular stock or ETF were in support of my approach, then I would go for it. IF the market dipped OR if I felt that I was trading just to trade, then I would sit on the sidelines for that day and wait for a better support level on any given equity. So, out of a possible 253 trading days, I ended up day / week trading on 118 days and averaged a return of $293.15 per day that I actually traded. . So, as we rolled into 2021, where I do expect a substantive pull back, I have been playing with SPY puts (in anticipation of some pullback with a June expirations), and I rolled in and out of CVS, multiple times, to create about $1,400 of profit in 2 days. 

I can tell you first hand, if you have the cash on the sidelines to play with, that day trading is a viable revenue stream (especially if you're working from home), however, you have to have discipline AND, I would say, most importantly, that you have to play with quality day trading names. Most of my profit was made on the following day trade names: Amazon, Google, CVS, RVLV, DBX, QCOM, AMEX, LYB, FB, SWKS, GS, C, ADBE, etc...My thinking on these names was that if there was another massive drop, like we had in March / April, that I didn't mind holding these names for the long term BUT, at the same time, based on reading the charts, they had substantial "support" levels at particular prices, Amazon, specifically, would seemingly bounce off of $3,000 virtually everytime it hit that price. 

In any event, I am really curious to see if I can hit the $100,000 mark in 2021, so far I am off to a good start, but if anyone is looking for additional tips OR for some guidance on my thought process and how I approach it, private message me and I'm happy to share additional details.

&#x200B;

Good luck trading everyone and happy new year.

author: louis_lafaille
body:
Microsoft was worth about $20b back in the early 90s when they launched Windows 3.1.  Global PC sales back then were ~30-40million units per year. That’s 1992 money we are talking about. No subscription revenue, just licensing. 

Global car sales is at around 80m units per year, and if BB’s OS becomes the dominate OS for automobiles (and there’s good reason to believe it will) I would put it at $40b minimum just based on the car OS aspect of the business alone. 

Asides, other cyber security firms are valued at 50+ ev/sales. Even if you apply the 50x multiple to ONLY the cyber security part of BB’s revenue it would already put Blackberry over $10b. That’s without the patents and without the Amazon partnership and without the Qualcomm Facebook settlements and without the household brand name and without the car OS and massive amount of data that they’re gonna harvest from QNX. 

So to answer your question.. i would price it at $20 today and $150 by the time QNX is in 50%+ of all vehicles on the road.

author: stockpicker69
body:
Bruh. I have PTSD from $BB. It was my first $100k bet that ate shit. Worst part, I bagheld it for way too long as it sat at $5-$6. I bought before the cylance acquisition because I thought I was being a genius thinking BB was basically a smaller qualcomm jr with all their parents. And I was super mad when qualcomm was in all that litigation with apple that I didn't buy on my thesis that it was super undervalued and the lawsuit was just giving bad vibes to the price. Well, cylance acquisition comes along and it jumps from like $8 to $10. I thought I was on a momentum train. Little did I realize I was on a train to baghold central. I held and it ate more shit. It wasn't until I forgot who told me to free up that capital and eat the 20%ish loss on it and get it back on another play. That's when everything changed. The problem was I kept seeing the $20k gone. Not that it was 20%. Now I think of everything in %. 

So do I think the same way about BB? ABSOLUTELY NOT. FK JOHN CHEN. TOOK THAT ASSHOLE A YEAR TO REALIZE HE NEEDS TO SELL THE FKING PATENTS TO CELLPHONES WHEN THE FKING COMPANY DOESN'T EVEN MAKE THEM ANYMORE?! IN FACT, THEY FKING LICENSE THEIR NAME OUT FOR THE ONES YOU SEE TODAY!! I WAS WAITING FOREVER. AND I KNOW HELLA OTHER BAG HOLDERS WERE/ARE TOO. 

Am I bitter? Probably. Am I biased? Damn straight. But for real, the GME situation and the BB situation are not even in the same area code. They are not comparable situations. So in closing, FK JOHN CHEN. FK BRAINASIUM. I QUIT.

author: kezlorek
body:
Nokia has some great upside, in my view.   I've been in since I saw it at $4 last year, thinking it is good to just hold in case it is a big 5G winner.

Huawei is one of the big 5G equipment makers out there but they are [restricted](https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-47041341) in parts of Europe and also in the US.  The restrictions in the US do expire this year, so if the new administration extends them, the news should cause all 5G stocks to go up just on that decision.

There is also the idea that once they get highly profitable again, they will reinstate the dividend which will likely cause the stock price to get a nice boost.  Their current P/E ratio is 46 so they really need to generate a ton of profits to get that down, but they have the potential.

Nokia also owns a lot of patents, but so do many others, and upholding them or enforcing them is probably very costly; it is not clear if the ones they hold are worth more than what everyone else has (Huawei, Samsung, Qualcomm, Intel, ZTE, Ericsson, etc.)

author: Worf_Of_Wall_St
body:
Regarding VR..

I really appreciate what Facebook has done for VR, and at or below cost to consumers which has really helped grow the audience size.  However, the "sleeping" giant here is Apple, and I'm not sure how well Facebook will be able to compete with whatever Apple eventually does.

Unlike smartphones, where the fidelity of the user experience on a 3 year old phone isn't really that different from the latest phones today, the minimum fidelity required for VR to see massive adoption is *beyond* what current reasonably-priced hardware is capable of.

VR gaming today is fun, but for games fidelity isn't nearly as important as gameplay.  An example of this is how Nintendo continues to create very successful consoles despite always being at least 1 generation behind its competitors in performance and fidelity.  

But most people just are not gamers.  For mass market appeal, VR/AR has to move beyond gaming to have experiences like virtual conferencing and multiplayer virtual tourism (which do already exist) that are *so realistic* that people prefer them to current flat screen options and are willing to pay for a new device just to have that capability.

VR performance and fidelity is all about vertical integration, and Apple is undisputed king here.  The recent M1 chip is an example of that prowess, and it'll almost certainly be that Apple's AR/VR devices will be based on a future generation of it.  For a device you wear on your face, industry-leading fan-less performance per watt is a massive edge.

The rumor is that Facebook has been working on their own chips, to replace the Qualcomm CPU/GPUs they use today, but it's not easy to create this capability from scratch in just a few years.

In Facebook's favor though is the network effect and platform lock-in (lose purchases if you switch) of being one of the first to market with a device selling several million units.

author: Green_Lantern_4vr
body:
> Just looking at financials alone and the amount of $ revenue they bring in compared to the industry standards, $BB stock price seemed quite undervalued in comparison. 


Why? What math? 2020 is only year revenue went up. 


> Amazon on a EV platform around data sensors, automation, and cybersecurity.


What rumors. There was the EV platform rumors but that’s all. EV have sensors so sure. Automation as in self driving? Sure but QNX IVY isn’t about self driving and would be very late to the game if it was. So industrial automation? 


Cyber security with Cylance? It made $50m for them and cost $1.4b. 


>FB suit


How much? 


> SpaceX, Zoom, Qualcomm, governments, and many more are working with $BB as we speak today. Sony recently just announced their partnership with $BB for their next upcoming car last week. Overall, lots of exciting news back to back.


Sources. Links. Spacex - for what ? QNX rocket?  Zoom? For what? Data integrity when it already has a China backdoor? Qualcomm? For what ? 


BB has worked with some gov historically but specifically on what? 


Sony partnership. Cool. Sony doesn’t make cars. They made 1 and said they weren’t selling it. BB also gets $5 a car fee. 


> This all depends if $BB is capable of hiring great salespeople to execute on their job. Only time will tell.

Nobody wants to work there. They have lots of job postings for that reason. Would you rather work at BB and get paid less $ and get worthless options or work at GOOG and get valuable options and paid more $? 


The way I see it is it potentially was overlooked and revenue is growing. That’s the only possibility for it’s up value to be real. 


Stocks are overlooked all the time. 


Maybe no profit last 4yr because reinvesting and research expenses etc. and accounting write downs (non cash). But cash flow from ops is also negative I think, or not great. 


EV or not, car sales are probably not spiking any time soon so nothing changed on the sales front for BB IVY, unless these new deals are guaranteed revenue. We’d have to know their details. 


Tech price to sales is 5-10x. MSFT is at 10 P/S. Is BB on par with MSFT? 

BB was at 3-4 P/S and now is at 7.5 P/S which is more reasonable for them. (TTM - trailing 12mo) (https://ycharts.com/companies/BB/ps_ratio)


P/S doesn’t factor in growth of the future. If sales growth then the ratio will go down unless the stock goes down.


 If we can confirm based on the items above that BB sales will increase (which, without the details to confirm it I would argue yes; how much, unknown) then there is room for BB price to increase. 


BB price is fair to increase a bit from its current price as well to perhaps 8.50x P/S. That would put the stock at $14.11. 


Throw in some growth there and in a year it wouldn’t be unreasonable to see **$18.43 share price. **


Again this assumes the initial above points are all vetted and the revenue is strong.

author: NotDaveofSpades
body: David Vs. Goliath story here. Qualcomm has been trying to put ParkerVision out of business for 8 years now so it doesn’t need to pay royalties for using Parkervision technology. They have willfully infringed on PRKR patents. Upcoming trial in May could result in multi-billon dollar verdict - and shares today ($1/share) will be worth north of $10/share. PRKR just received positive markman ruling in case vs Intel. Positive markman ruling generally signals positive court ruling. PRKR also received positive markman ruling vs. QCOM. Other patent infringement lawsuits against Apple and other companies that are using chips to empower WiFi, Bluetooth applications in TVs and anything IOT.  Shares ran from $0.35 / share to $1.05 share last week after Intel Markman ruling. Will run further ahead of the QCOM trial when PRKR executes licensing agreements with Chinese TV companies TCL and Hisense.  Support Parkervision in its battle against these tech giants. #DavidvsGoliath

author: AquaVR
body:
I asked Boz (head of AR/VR at Facebook) what he thought of the Apple VR headset rumors and he said “Not really, and I don’t meant to be glib about it, I’d love to have more people putting more VR headsets out there, it’s good for consumers. I’m a little skeptical if that’s really what Apple is going to do, given I don’t know where their content is going to come from, but you know, they’re great so I hope they do.". Boz should be pretty informed and he thinks that they aren't going for VR in the way the public thinks, and that they don't have content ready. 

Mark Gurman thinks Apple is coming out with a far above $1000 priced headset in 2022. In either of those scenario, I think Facebook remains dominant long enough for their chip investment to pay off.

I know Apple has a chip advantage now, but it doesn't seem like they are going to try to compete directly with Facebook in VR, which I think is a mistake on their behalf.

As far as fidelity on Qualcomm chips, I personally don't see an problem thus far, and they already have upgrade paths for the next iteration of Quest.

body:
I remember the hysteria too. I was investing in Microsoft, Apple, Qualcomm, and Home Depot at that time. Trades were $10/each at that point. Most people outside of finance had never heard about an "ETF". We were also seeing 6.5% CD rates in 2000. We didn't have iPhones back then, but my Lexus had a "car phone". Enjoyed the ride up in 1999, and saw much of that money erode come 2000. However, since I still had a job, I was able to continue to buy in 2000 when things were going down. Made my first $1M after 2 drawdown periods (1999 and 2008); $150k invested over 12 years (I'd try to put in $1k/month most months, and a bit extra when I could) turned into $1M.

There's just so much more information and knowledge available now, and the folks of today don't seem to have a problem with holding through drawdowns. I look at the "new investments" like Bitcoin in amazement, and not because of the parabolic moves, but because so many people have been holding on through 80% drawdowns. I've never seen such an iron conviction before. Folks of today are not afraid of drawdowns or volatility. Additionally, between all of our corporations, we're pumping in billions of new dollars every single week into the market now.

Times have changed, and you're kidding yourself if you haven't seen the change.

author: storman121
body:
TSMC is preparing to mass produce 3nm chips for our favorite tech companies: Apple, Qualcomm and Nvidia. This will be happening in the year 2022. The year Intel will be rolling out the then-obsolete 7nm chips. Pat better come up with something real fast!  


[https://www.scmp.com/tech/innovation/article/3118183/tsmc-gears-mass-production-3-nanometre-chips-high-end-computers-and](https://www.scmp.com/tech/innovation/article/3118183/tsmc-gears-mass-production-3-nanometre-chips-high-end-computers-and)

author: LeilaniOtter
body:
I bought 100 NOK this week on advice from a friend. It bothered me that this stock has never been hardly over $60 in its whole life, and I've been using Nokia phones since they first came out. How does a phone company that was once number one in the world never have more than a $60 value in the market? Answer: the iPhone, and when it debuted in 2007, it sent 90% of NOK's value down the toilet. Virtually destroyed the company. What can it do now? What brings it back from the dead? 

5G. It's the new mania and it's going to take a lot of companies to the top again. Nokia is the leader of 5G technology thanks to their association with Qualcomm (the undisputed masters of 5G right now), and usually...well, in most cases, the one leading the group is always ahead. AT&T had to delay their 5G slightly when it was ready to go in June 2020 (thanks, COVID =P) and they cover only about 17k cities and towns, (and you just know for them to say it like that, it's hardly a huge slice of the market and they know it \^\^) so guess who's lagging behind already? Meanwhile, NOK keeps gobbling up contracts around the world as of 2020, and there's already a whole host of positive news in this month alone.

NOK is a great play, and don't be too surprised to see it get to $60 again. This is something to hold long-term.

author: skwirly715
body:
I don’t know. It is generally best to do your own research in this regard. There are many variables at play for any given security. You will find that there are many, many, many strategies that claim to take advantage of market nuance in the manner you are beginning to consider here. Most experts will want you to pay them for access to those strategies and recommendations. 

I can’t give you financial advice. I dont personally feel the market for taking advantage of squeezes is ripe right now. Maybe it will return in the future. I don’t generally invest that way so I don’t fucking know. Not a financial advisor. My suggestion is to buy QQQ, VOO, Disney, Qualcomm, Visa, BJK, ESPO, Lyft, Uber, and ICLN. Those are the holdings of my actual portfolio ordered from greatest to least amount of equity. But that’s not financial advice, just an opinion.

Their strategy has been to wait till the companies go bankrupt.  This case against Qualcomm will be one of the largest patent litigation settlements in history. The legal team representing parkervision are the best in the industry. Look at Qualcomm’s history of violations. Their markman rulings against intel and Qualcomm are important. Share at less than a dollar now. Upside is huge. See research reports.

author: SenorPina
body:
They're really not comparable. TSMC and Samsung are the only companies making 5nm chips, the process node that Apple, AMD, Qualcomm, and others are using for their most advanced products. TSMC really can't fail here unless demand dries up since they're the only game in town with the technology to make these devices.

UMC doesn't have any foundries making smaller than 14nm chips, which is relatively ancient, so don't expect any orders from the big names. They're likely fulfilling mostly orders for chips that don't need the absolute fastest, bleeding edge manufacturing tech. I don't personally know if that end of the market is expected to grow along with the higher end chips, but that is the principal difference between the two companies.

author: _MoveSwiftly
body:
I completely understand this.

I do think ARM based chips will beat any x86 on power and potentially even speed. AMD is providing the graphics chip to Qualcomm based CPUs (Samsung specifically) and that gives me hope that they're not neglecting that. Lisa Su is no fool either, she knows what's going on in the market and keeping an eye out for it.

Their Xiling acquisition could play a part in all of this, though I doubt it. They do have it so we'll see.

I did buy a large chunk in QCOM today after I heard about Nuvia. I researched each of the owners and their goals. QCOM specifically mentioned benefiting their mobile lineup, but did not mention server side CPUs even though that's Nuvia's main goal. What was that about? Either way, I believe it'll go through with no issues, the press release lists so many companies in support of the acquisition.

author: Caffeine_Monster
body:
Get the fundamentals right first: revenue growth and earnings per share - pretty basic stuff. Does the company look overvalued or undervalued? Are they stagnant, or growing?

For me the next big thing is understanding the product or service the company sells. How is it better than the competition? Is it a growing market? What does the product roadmap look like? End of the day the market has to like the product - it is your job to understand why the market willl like it.

e.g. TSMC is one of the stocks I like at the moment:

\- Industry leader in high performance 7nm semiconductors

\- Supplies a number of the other big tech companies: Nvidia, AMD, Apple,  Qualcomm , Mediatek, (And soon to Intel)

\- Good EPS

\- New fabs in production

\- On track to deliver 5nm nodes

\- Demand for computer hardware driving up fab demand - there is a massive hardware shortage at the moment

\- Pays a decent dividend

author: nyunaii
body:
This is a brilliant long-term play:

Now is very possibly a turning point for the automotive industry, which has a precedent in the semi industry.

In the 1980s the semi industry was dominated by large, vertically integrated companies (think Intel, IBM, ...)

The high (and ever increasing) capital needed for building factories was a problem for startups and stifled innovation. Startups had to enter into deals with OEMs (often competitors) to manufacture their chips. 

1987 : enter TSMC, pioneered the contract manufacturing model. Startups now had a partner which was 1. Dedicated to their customers success (win-win) and 2. Not a competitor in the marketplace

Those startups are the likes of : NVDA, QCOM.

Decades later, where are NVDA, QCOM, TSM ? Tendie town. How about INTC, IBM ? There you go.
